Provides training in legal and ethical issues as they pertain to the professional practice of behavior analysis . Reviews the Guidelines for Responsible Conduct for Behavior Analysts , as well as the American Psychological Association’s Ethical Principles of Psychologists and Code of Conduct .

course_name: PSYC 587 Practicum in Applied Behavior Analysis
description: Provides supervised practical experience in implementing behavior analytic assessment and treatment services . Meets supervision requirements for the Board Certified Behavior Analyst exam . Students meet with course instructor to present and discuss cases for two hours per week every semester , including one summer session . Practicum hours in the field vary from 18-20 hours per week during the academic year to 30 hours per week during the summer .
Review of theories of cognitive development . Analysis of research on brain functioning , perception , memory , language , reasoning and academic skills from birth to adolescence .

course_name: PSYC 535 Research Methods in Behavior Analysis
description: Survey of methods for measuring behavior . Examines theoretical background for single subject research methods , practical application of research methods to treatment evaluation , and analyzes strengths and limitations of single subject research methods .

course_name: Social and Emotional Development in Children
description: Theories of social and emotional development , including sociocultural perspectives . Analysis of research on temperament , social relationships , individuation and moral development from birth to adolescence .

course_name: PSYC 537 Development and Supervision of Intervention Systems
description: Analyzes evidence-based approaches to designing behavior change systems at the individual , family , group , and organizational levels . Examines family and systems variables that affect the likelihood of initial and continued success of interventions .

course_name: PSYC 597a Capstone Project in Behavior Analysis

course_name: FBE 535 Applied Finance in Fixed Income Securities
description: The basic principles underlying fixed income securities and how these principles apply to the practical aspects of fixed income management .
Introduction to the investment strategies used by hedge funds , the quantitative tools and business plans used to implement them .

Theories , practices , and technologies of trading at exchanges and in dealer networks . Sources of liquidity , volatility , profitability , and institutional change . Domestic and international public policy issues .

Business law of traditional and e-contracts , UCC , crimes , torts , employment , ethics , social responsibility , intellectual property , digital law , e-commerce , accountants’ liability , property , estates , and government regulation .

course_name: FBE 558 Law for Structuring , Financing , and Managing Businesses
description: Legal environment of agency law , general and limited partnerships , limited liability companies , corporate formation and financing , corporate governance , securities law , acquisitions , bankruptcy , and business ethics .
Analysis of commodity , futures , and options contracts ; theoretical and empirical approaches ; spot and futures price relationships , speculation and hedging strategies ; market efficiency .

Practical application of the critical components of mergers and acquisitions : deal flow strategies , preliminary negotiations , deal structures , due diligence , valuation , post-merger integration , and regulations .

course_name: FBE 562 Current Issues in International Finance
description: International monetary relations , financial markets , and institutions ; theory and evidence of alternative approaches to balance of payments ; current policy evaluation .
Comparative advantage and gains from trade ; factor proportions and efficiency ; factor price equalization ; terms of trade ; tariffs , customs , unions and trade agreements .

course_name: FBE 571 Introduction to Financial Analysis : Practicum
description: This introductory financial analysis (tools , techniques) practicum , emphasizes practical application of asset valuation and portfolio management techniques for those with little previous experience .
Concepts underlying the economic analysis of engineering projects ; applications to call and put options ; utility theory and mathematical optimizations models ; and simulation .

course_name: Mathematics and Tools for Financial Engineering
description: Students will build a mathematical background for studying financial engineering . Emphasis is on analysis , proofs and examples . Mathwork’s financial toolbox will be introduced .

course_name: Economic and Financial Time Series I
description: Simultaneous equation models , dynamic structural econometric models , vector autoregressions , causality , forecasting , univariate and multivariate nonstationary time series , tests for unit roots , cointegration , autoregressive conditional heteroscedasticity models , time series models with changes in regime .

course_name: CE 645 Uncertainty Modeling and Stochastic Optimization
description: Introduction to the mathematical foundations , numerical algorithms , and computational tools necessary for solving problems of optimization under uncertainty .

course_name: EE 500 Neural Learning and Computational Intelligence
description: Computational intelligence techniques that include neural systems , deep learning , adaptive pattern classification , fuzzy function approximation , simulated annealing and evolutionary computing , and hybrid systems .

course_name: EE 517 Statistics and Data Analysis for Engineers
description: Statistics and data analysis emphasizing computation and problem solving : confidence intervals , hypothesis tests , bootstrap and Monte Carlo estimation , regression , Bayesian and statistical learning techniques .

Stochastic system models , Dynamic programming , Linear quadratic control , Kalman filtering and estimation , System identification , approximate dynamic programming methods , adaptive control and online learning .

Simulation techniques combined with probabilistic analysis for solving problems in inventory theory , queuing theory , financial engineering , decision analysis , and other fields having a stochastic element .
Investigation of creative problems through various media . Course may be repeated .

course_name: Making and Curating Art : Pedagogy and Praxis
description: (Enroll in CRIT 525 )

course_name: ART 530 Global Art Seminar : the Globalization of Art and Culture
description: An examination of the emergence of the idea of “globalism” through the lens of art practice and theory .
Presentation and critique which builds students’ skills in presenting and contextualizing their artwork for peer review ; analytic discussion regarding directions in contemporary art .
Credit on acceptance of Thesis .
The unique characteristics and importance of spatial information as they relate to the evolving science , technology , and applications of Geographic Information Systems .
Design , implementation , and interrogation of relational , object-oriented and other types of geospatial databases .
Role of global positioning systems , maps , geocoding , and other kinds of sensors as geospatial data sources . Includes field data acquisition excursion on Catalina Island .
Credit on acceptance of thesis .
Provides the knowledge and skills necessary to investigate the spatial patterns which result from social and physical processes operating at or near the Earth’s surface .
The use of spatial models to describe social and environmental processes , patterns and systems at multiple spatial and temporal scales .
Concepts , principles , and use of project management tools and the people issues encountered running GIS projects .
Design , coding , and implementation of GIS-based software and models using the Python programming language .
Principles of remote sensing , satellite systems , and role of remote sensing data in GIS applications .
Principles of visual perception , spatial cognition and cartographic design and their contributions to the maps , animations , virtual reality and multimedia displays produced with modern GIS .
Design and implementation of locally served and cloud-based geospatial web applications . Construction of web maps , mashups , and Volunteered Geographic Information interfaces .
Design , coding , and implementation of mobile GIS applications using the Java and Javascript object-oriented programming languages .

Role of crowdsourcing , volunteered geographic information , spatial data infrastructures , and web portals in helping with the collection , storage , curation , and distribution of geospatial data assets .

course_name: GDEN 710 Knowledge Assessment for GDEN Students
description: Review of topics explored in the first two years of the program , including lectures and practical demonstrations or simulations and examinations of overall discipline knowledge .

course_name: GDEN 711a Case Portfolio Preparation for GDEN Students
description: Examination of clinical cases of geriatric patients through online conferences . Development and defense of portfolio of multiple cases . Open only to master’s and professional dental students .

course_name: GDEN 712a Capstone Research Project for GDEN Students
description: Production and defense of a research plan that demonstrates significant understanding of a topic in geriatric dentistry .

course_name: Internal Medicine and Systemic Disease for Dental Residents
description: (Enroll in OFPM 722 )

course_name: Epidemiology , Nutrition and Aging for Dental Residents
description: (Enroll in OFPM 725 )

course_name: MEDS 503 L Core Principles System I
description: Introduction to basic medical concepts and biological system functions ; examination of core principles of science and medical treatment .

course_name: MEDS 504 L Core Principles System II
description: Continuation of concepts from MEDS 503  . Basic medical concepts and biological system functions ; examination of core principles of science and medical treatment .
Develop conceptual and practical knowledge in entrepreneurship and new venture management .
Study and development of analytical and conceptual skills in the management of new enterprises and new ventures within large organizations .
A conceptual framework for understanding global challenges faced in the management of non-communicable diseases , including heart disease , diabetes , chronic lung disease , and cancer .

course_name: MEDS 580 Interprofessional Team Dynamics in Healthcare
description: Examination of typical composition and function of interprofessional healthcare teams . Exploration of roles of team members and purview of care issues and common challenges , including medication management , inpatient/outpatient decision making , and care plan implementation .

course_name: MEDS 581 Case Studies in Interprofessional Healthcare
description: Survey of the specific roles each member of an interprofessional health team plays in the provision of care , based on their professional training . Application of diverse health professional expertise to case studies in healthcare .

course_name: DSO 582 Service Management : Economics and Operations
description: Examination of the service industry from a managerial and entrepreneurial perspective ; emphasis on the tactical decisions needed to design and deliver successful and profitable services .

Critical issues in international control and treatment of malaria . Exploration of biological and epidemiological fundamentals of human-parasite interaction , including dynamics of transmission among populations .

Exploration of biological and epidemiological fundamentals of tuberculosis including dynamics of transmission among populations . Overview of clinical manifestations , diagnosis , and treatment of infections .

course_name: Global Health Modules , Maternal and Child Health I
description: Biopsychosocial , cultural and economic aspects of women’s health : pregnancy , childbirth , marriage . Examination of health promotion and policy efforts to improve women’s health globally .

course_name: Global Health Modules , Maternal and Child Health II
description: In-depth examination of women’s health issues ; health promotion and policy efforts to improve women’s health globally .

Examination of prevalent tropical diseases : epidemiology , clinical manifestations , treatment , impact on economies of tropical countries . Key issues related to these diseases ; World Health Organization responses .

HIV epidemiology , basic biology of transmission and pathophysiology , associated opportunistic infections , and challenges to providing care in the developing world , including government responses .

course_name: Cultural Competence in Health and Medicine
description: Practical approach to the development of professional skills for providing culturally sensitive clinical health services to ethnically and linguistically diverse patients .
The relationship between health and human rights , and the study of human rights issues relevant to health care professionals .

course_name: MEDS 518 Children in Emergency Situations : Global Policies and Programs
description: Focuses on children in emergency situations , including natural and man-made disasters , such as floods , earthquakes , conflicts , or war , with an emphasis on the poorest and most vulnerable children .

Better understand the key issues impacting global oral health , how better care can help reduce the disease prevalence , and ways to prepare the next generation of global health leaders to address the key issues .

course_name: MEDS 520 Medical Spanish for the Health Professions
description: Spanish language course for students planning to enter the health professions .
Exploration of the threat of major worldwide epidemics and diseases with a focus on the recent emergence of new plagues .
Human hepatitis and the viruses that cause them , how they are spread , symptoms , treatment , and prevention .
Covers the occurrences of toxic substances and the toxicity/diseases they cause , and chemical carcinogens and the types of cancer they cause worldwide .
Instruction on the process and methods of writing effective grants from identifying appropriate funders to implementing project upon receipt of funding award .
Examines the major mental health diagnoses from clinically relevant perspectives and their prevalence in specific geographical regions around the world .

course_name: Alternative and Eastern Medicine : A Biomedical Approach
description: Exploration of issues of complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) and traditional Eastern medical views of health and illness from a Western biomedical perspective .

Background information on a group of infections that are transmitted via animal contact . Understanding of the epidemiology , clinical manifestations , treatment , and impact of the diseases on the economies of the countries in which they are found .

course_name: Global Health Modules , Sexually Transmitted Infections
description: Examines clinically relevant perspectives from distinguished international authors on STI issues and the devastating effect on particular geographical regions around the world .
Introduction to refugee health care and life events which impact health . Discuss medical needs of long-term displaced populations with specific case studies .

course_name: MEDS 531 The Politics of Global Health
description: Examines the impact of politics on global health progress and declines .

Examination of microbial and human cells as versatile therapeutic engines , including their novel applications : autologous and allogenic immunotherapies , stem cell technologies , and human microbiome transplantations .

Examination of the entrepreneurial process in biotechnology , including : industry overview , idea generation , business plan formulation , intellectual property protection , funding , personnel management , and regulatory body interaction .
Overview of national and international variations in health status indicators in regard to cultural and lifestyle differences .

course_name: Clinical Medicine and Health Care Reform in Taiwan
description: Two-week in-depth study abroad in Taipei , Taiwan , focused on understanding Taiwan’s health care system , health priorities , and needs .

course_name: Clinical Medicine and Socioeconomic Factors in Uganda
description: Two-week course that provides students with hands-on experience in clinical medicine/public health and exposure to the various socioeconomic factors impacting health in the developing world .

course_name: Clinical Medicine and Health Care Reform in Jordan
description: A two-week , in-depth study abroad course that explores the economic , social , political , and health issues in the Middle East region and specifically Jordan .

course_name: Clinical Medicine and Health Care Challenges in India
description: Two-week study abroad course that explores the health dynamics and health care settings of India .

course_name: MEDS 554 Clinical Medicine and Healthcare Delivery in Panama
description: A two-week course providing students with hands-on experience in the practice of rural medicine as they gain exposure to the various socio-economic factors present in Bocas del Toro , Panama .

course_name: MEDS 555 Clinical Medicine and Healthcare Access in Honduras
description: A three-week hybrid course providing students with hands-on experience in clinical medicine/public health and exposure to the various socio-economic factors impacting healthcare delivery in the developing world , specifically in Honduras .

course_name: MEDS 556 Global Health Field Study , New York
description: Two-week course providing students with a solid understanding of the United Nations’ major agencies influential in global health , their mandate , their strengths and challenges . Includes field visit to selected UN organizations all located in NYC .

course_name: MEDS 557 Clinical Medicine and Healthcare Dynamics in Denmark
description: Two-week course that provides a venue for careful examination and assessment of the economic , social , political , and specific health issues currently faced by countries in the European Region .

course_name: MEDS 558 Clinical Medicine and Translational Research in Argentina
description: Two week in-depth course examining and assessing the economic , social , political and unique health issues faced by the Latin- American Region especially Argentina .

course_name: MEDS 559 Clinical Medicine and Healthcare Determinants in China
description: A two-week intensive course abroad in Shanghai , China , focused on understanding clinical realities of Chinese medicine , health determinants and healthcare delivery .
Two-week study abroad course in Malaysia that examines the capacity of local communities to address health needs and to address health priorities with innovation .

course_name: MEDS 561 Global Healthcare Development and Practices in Nepal
description: Two-week course providing a multi-faceted understanding of the delivery of essential services to underserved populations , particularly women and children , in the challenging Nepalese healthcare landscape .
Research leading to the master’s degree . Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department .
Two-week course that provides students opportunities to analyze and gain exposure to public health and health systems infrastructure in Thailand .

course_name: Global Healthcare Development and Social Justice in Italy
description: A two-week course analyzing global healthcare access and delivery through the lens of development economics , social justice , health advocacy , and Italian medical history and research .

course_name: Health Behavior and Healthcare in Germany
description: Two-week course that exposes students to public health and health systems infrastructure in Germany and Switzerland , including analysis of health behaviors .
Two-week study abroad course in Fiji that examines the public health and healthcare systems of Fiji and its neighbors .
Lecture and discussion focused on specific topics within global medicine . Course topic will vary from semester to semester .
A systematic survey of basic and clinical nutrition that provides an overview of critical public health-nutrition issues in both the developing world and industrial society .
Examination of medical issues in aging through a nation-specific survey of how various countries treat the elderly in health policy and healthcare .

Focus on the importance of evidence-based practice in healthcare . Development of critical thinking and analysis of scientific literature to enable the identification and appropriate implementation of medical , cultural , and ethical interventions in healthcare , particularly through interdisciplinary collaboration .

Introduction to the field of narrative medicine . Examination of theoretical and literary texts and the practice of narrative and reflective writing to enhance narrative competency and gain an understanding of the role of narrative in people’s experiences with illness .
Application of operations management tools and techniques to improve the performance of healthcare delivery systems . May include international travel .

course_name: MOR 542 Strategic Issues for Global Business
description: Globalization strategies from entry to maturity ; alternative approaches from going alone to alliances ; strategy implementation issues in different cultures and political systems . Cases , videos and speakers .
Comprehensive study of Six Sigma and Lean metrics , methods , and systems with their applications to manufacturing , services , quality improvement and management .
Improving operations , patient flow , quality and processes . Students will become familiar with methods for implementing change in health care settings such as hospitals or clinics .
Variations in markets and trade patterns around the globe ; product development and adaptation , pricing , promotion , and distribution issues across national cultures and international markets .

course_name: DSO 549 Application of Lean Six Sigma
description: Application of Six Sigma practices and techniques to improve operations in organizations . Open only to graduate business students .

course_name: DSO 557a Global Supply Chain Management in International Settings
description: Study of global logistics infrastructures – water , rail , road , and air – through readings , team research and presentation , international site visits , and final written report . Open only to Global Supply Chain Management majors .
Issues in supply chain management . Supply chain performance and dynamics . Tools for planning , control and coordination . Supply chain design and strategy . Open only to business majors .
The role of enterprise resource planning systems (ERPs) in an organization and the task of implementing and managing the IS function .

Sustainability concepts and frameworks , design for environment , closed-loop supply chains , sustainability in sourcing , green facilities , renewable energy , facility location and transportation decisions , strategic sustainability implementation . Web registration open only to graduate business and accounting students .

Factors to consider when making sourcing decisions (costs , prices , ethics , globalization) ; impact of sourcing on other activities such as product design or inventory management . Open only to graduate business students .

Gives students a managerial knowledge of basic logistics concepts and principles . Some topics include management of logistics cost integration , transportation , distribution , and customer service . Open only to graduate business students .

course_name: DSO 534 Discrete-Event Simulation for Process Management
description: Application of discrete-event simulation models to events that occur randomly over time . Representation using process flow diagrams . Use of simulation methodology to improve process performance .

Applications of systems theory and concepts , matrix organizational structures , PERT/CPM project modeling , and management information systems to the management of complex and critical projects . Open only to business majors .

Deterministic and stochastic demand systems with static/dynamic models . Practice in inventory management , computerized procedures , materials requirements planning , just-intime production , Kanban systems .
Advanced concepts in production planning and scheduling including resource allocation , lot sizing , flow shop and job shop scheduling , workforce scheduling and assembly line balancing .
Principles of quality management , quality philosophies and frameworks , quality leadership and strategic planning , process management , and performance measurements .
Concepts and methods to analyze the environmental impacts of industrial systems , including lifecycle assessment , material flow analysis , design for environment and sustainable consumption .
Management and engineering strategies utilized to improve energy efficiency .

course_name: AME 577 Survey of Energy and Power for a Sustainable Future
description: Power production includes conventional fossil fuels , synthetic fuels , hydroelectric , solar , wind , geothermal , biomass and nuclear . The environmental consequences of various energy sources are discussed .
Environmental effects of energy development using fossil and fissile fuels , geothermics , photosynthesis , and other sources . Relationship of elemental cycles to the life supporting systems .

course_name: Sustainability in the Environment : Infrastructures , Urban Landscapes , and Buildings
description: Methodologies and exercises on contextual design and environmentally sound technologies (EST’s) applications for the sustainability of urban infrastructures , operative landscapes , and building integration in the urban system .
Examination of smart infrastructures relating to energy , water , waste and transportation drawing from the fields of engineering , sustainability , communications , sociology , and psychology .
Federal and state environmental laws ; environmental impact assessment techniques ; permitting for industrial facility construction and operation .

course_name: MOR 566 Environmental Sustainability and Competitive Advantage
description: How business is changing in order to respond to environmental sustainability challenges — adapting strategy , product design , operations , marketing , and accounting . Cases and speakers .

course_name: HMGT 512 Information Technology and Patient Engagement
description: Strategic management and utilization of healthcare information technology in the delivery of healthcare ; patient engagement and the use of technology to facilitate participation in their own care .

course_name: Leading People and Health Care Organizations
description: An exploration of contemporary work force issues and skills development in organizational design , performance measurement , teamwork , conflict resolution , leadership , and change management .
Provides a framework for the economic analysis of health care issues and provides students with an opportunity to apply economic methods to a number of actual health care problems .
Executives confront and solve problems requiring use of accounting , finance , and management control principles ; provides core financial skills for non-finance professionals .
Provides skill development and application in the integrative discipline of strategic management including assessment , strategy formulation , implementation and control .
Methods for monitoring and improving the health of populations . Topics include outcomes management , risk-adjustment , development and implementation of practice guidelines .

Overview of reimbursement models in clinical and institutional settings ; legal , financial and clinical assumption of risk pursuant to new and evolving federal and state statutory and regulatory provisions .

Hospital operations in the inpatient/outpatient setting ; special emphasis on the growing requirement to more effectively manage across the continuum of care while assuming greater accountability in the delivery of care .

course_name: HMGT 602 Operational Efficiency Processes in Health Care Organizations
description: Improving productivity and efficiency of health care organizations combining the application of key operational analysis principles to improve quality , speed and productivity in the delivery of health care .

course_name: HMGT 603 Developing and Monitoring of Quality and Patient Safety Outcomes
description: Overview of contemporary methods used to develop and monitor patient quality and safety outcomes ; develop skill in data collection and analysis of clinical care outcomes ; focus on operationalizing outcomes that matter to payers , organizations , and clinicians .
Conceptual framework for data base development ; relational data management ; use of health statistics ; health indicators ; confidentiality , security , privacy .

Quality issues and complexities affecting health care ; fundamentals of quality improvement programs ; examination of quality issues and improvement programs in various health care venues ; strategies .

course_name: PPD 605 Frontline Issues in Health Services Administration and Policy
description: Emphasis on current or emergent issues in the health care industry . Focus on impact of recent health legislation and/or health care system responsiveness .

Accounting principles , financial reports , managerial finance , financial planning , capital investments , working capital analysis ; elements of budgeting and reimbursement ; performance standards ; reporting ; developing a management system .
Supervised study of health care administration , governance , professional staff relations , internal operations and controls , legal and regulatory requirements , management policy and strategy .

course_name: PPD 513 Legal Issues in Health Care Delivery
description: Rights of consumers ; health-related powers of governments ; rights and responsibilities of health care providers ; interrelationships of rights , powers , and responsibilities .

course_name: PPD 514 Economic Concepts Applied to Health
description: Relationships between economic characteristics and health status ; impact of economy on health services industry ; demand and resources for health services ; utilization , prices , costs , health insurance .
Application of principles of health administration in several practice settings . Decision-making ; strategic management ; organizational performance ; communication ; provider comparisons .

course_name: PPD 516 Financial Accounting for Health Care Organizations
description: Accounting as a management tool ; accounting systems ; basic accounting concepts and procedures ; budgets ; financial statements .

course_name: Concepts and Practices in Managing Health Care Organizations
description: Application of principles of health administration . Role of managers ; managing people and programs ; human resource management concepts and applications ; working with professionals ; governance ; public relations .

course_name: PPD 545 Human Behavior in Public Organizations
description: Behavior in organizations ; focus on personal , interpersonal , and group level factors that influence such behavior .

Applied multivariate statistics in support of policy , management , and planning problem solving . Includes regression analysis , logit models , and an introduction to time-series models and multi-equation estimation .

course_name: Topics in Modern Architecture in Southern California
description: Investigation of modern architecture in southern California within its cultural and historic contexts .
Concepts and strategies for conservation of significant elements of the built environment : buildings , sites and communities as revealed by readings , site visits , and case studies .

Conservation practice within an economic , political , and cultural context looking at the regulatory environment , public advocacy and policy , real estate development , heritage tourism , environmental sustainability , cultural diversity , and interpretation .

Concepts and techniques for building conservation including identification of treatments , recordation and research , material properties and behavior , building forensics , and project implementation .

Survey of basic guidelines and standards for documentation in historic preservation , including cultural resource surveys , historic structures reports and Historic American Building Survey and Historic American Engineering Record recordation .

course_name: History of American Architecture and Urbanism
description: History of American architecture and urbanism from prehistory to World War II examined in relation to European influences and indigenous developments .

course_name: ARCH 554 Heritage Conservation Practicum — Advanced Documentation
description: Heritage conservation practicum utilizing in-depth documentation methodology to explore the historic built environment of greater Los Angeles . Topics will vary from year to year ; may be repeated for credit when subjectmatter is different .

course_name: ARCH 555 Global Perspectives in Heritage Conservation
description: In-depth analysis of international heritage conservation practice with a focus on a single country , continent , or world region outside the United States . Topics will vary from year to year ; may be repeated for credit when subject matter is different .
Trans-disciplinary intensive reading and discussion course related to issues in contemporary heritage conservation .
Concepts and strategies for urban design and place-making for heritage conservation as revealed by place-making exercises , site visits , and case studies .

course_name: ARCH 691a Heritage Conservation Thesis Preparation and Thesis
description: Introduction to , and exploration of , topics leading to the development of a thesis prospectus and directed research towards the completion of the master’s thesis in heritage conservation .

Explores the strategic role that human resources management plays in providing organizations with sustained competitive advantages by unlocking the productive potential of employees’ human and social capital .

course_name: HRM 505 Organizational Culture and Employee Outcomes
description: Prepares students to create , foster , and manage organizations in which people thrive and perform at their best in order to retain talent and reduce costs in a sustainable way .
Focuses on developing the critical social intelligence skills needed to lead people and change through increased self-awareness , understanding of interpersonal differences , and greater influence .
Equips students with a deeper understanding of how to design and develop organizations to increase performance and effectiveness and includes sections on strategy , work , and management processes .
Examines talent management processes that impact employee experience and engagement and explores ways to improve data driven decision making processes including workforce and succession planning .

Provides a comprehensive look at the employee rewards strategies that human resource practitioners promote and manage including compensation , performance management , benefits , and non-monetary rewards .
Prepares students to identify , design , and implement effective learning and development interventions and strategies that drive results and enhance organizational competitiveness .
Applies practical approaches to building positive employee and labor relations and solving related problems through increased employee motivation , effectiveness , and retention .
Examines and emphasizes strategies and techniques to enable improved organizational and human capital decisions by directing the organizational analytics for more actionable insights .

course_name: HRM 545 Management of Diverse and Global Human Resources
description: Analyzes global diversity in today’s environment , fostering a broad understanding of diversity and inclusion and the impact of diversity , inclusion , and inclusive behaviors on organizations .

course_name: HRM 550 Change Management and Organization Development
description: Identifies the common challenges in organizational change management and explores the limitations and opportunities of different models of organizational change .

course_name: HRM 555 Anticipating the Future of Human Resources
description: Explores the forces and emerging trends that are reshaping work , the workforce and workplace – and how to address these transformational changes and be effective as a Human Resources leader .

Planning data collection to investigate relationships between product/process design choices (materials , temperatures , etc .) and performance , empirical modeling to predict performance , identification of the best design choices .
One-week campus residential . Introduction to program themes , content , concepts , theories , and processes . Opportunity to build skills and meet cohort , with an emphasis on team building .

One-week off-campus residential . Visit WIRED headquarters , cultural venues , and businesses . Applied , intensive workshop format focused on solutions for real-world problems with input from industry experts .
Research leading to graduate degree . Maximum units which may be applied to degree determined by department .

Discipline-specific , cross-disciplinary , and shared approaches to products , services , projects , systems , organizational development . Topics include creative and user-focused perspectives , feasibility analytics , lean startup techniques .
culty-mentored project paired with a Core course . Demonstrate individual and simultaneous skills and competency across fields and within cross-functional , cross-disciplinary teams .

Discipline-specific , cross-disciplinary , and shared approaches to recognizing/analyzing opportunities , identifying/framing problems , and developing/iterating solutions . Techniques gleaned from entrepreneurship , creative practices , critical thinking methods , ethnography , systems theory .

Discipline-specific , cross-disciplinary , and shared approaches to exploring visual , written , and spoken storytelling using digital modalities . Topics include communication theory , narrative structures and content creation .
Generate portfolio of solutions for a given “problem .” Explore solutions and decisions , mechanisms for reducing uncertainty and risk . Includes quantitative and qualitative techniques .
culty-mentored , applied project with individual and team components . Implement a prototype solution to a problem . Deploy relevant tools , methods , and processes learned throughout the program .
Overview of design language , process and product . Build fluency in applying core visual principles and design-based problem-solving techniques . Explore historical and contemporary design issues .
Overview of general business and management concepts and techniques that builds theoretical and analytical fluency and identifies and examines leadership and managerial challenges .
Overview of core information technology concepts , methods , and frameworks . Develop aptitude in using tools , applications and systems ; learn basic programming languages and methodologies .
Optional short-term , primarily residential , learning experience paired with an event/activity . Intensive experience aligns with and extends the cross-disciplinary nature of the program .
Seminars on latest trends in interactive media content , technology , tools , business and culture .

course_name: CTIN 532 L Interactive Design and Production I
description: The development of interactive experiences with an emphasis on prototyping and development .
Interactive design , prototyping and testing of projects developed in CTIN 548  .
An advanced production workshop in which students design and prepare for the production of their advanced project .
Credit on acceptance of thesis .
In-depth investigation of publication , distribution , business and legal aspects of the interactive entertainment business .

course_name: IML 500 Digital Media Tools and Tactics
description: Introduction to digital scholarship at the graduate level , with a focus on media research ecologies , online portfolios and distributed scholarly presence . Open only to graduate students .
Advanced writing workshop addressing issues specific to interactive storytelling regarding construction of narrative and character as seen in games and other forms of interactive media .
The fundamentals of 3-D real time game engines , scripting for interactivity , and building games with digital tools .
Study and performance of vocal ensemble literature from the Jazz idiom , with emphasis on improvisational techniques .
Rehearsal and performance of literature written for large jazz ensemble .
Preparation and performance of advanced literature for jazz chamber groups .
Techniques , approaches , teaching materials , and music useful in developing jazz ensembles in educational settings , from junior high school through college .
Application of theoretical and compositional techniques used in jazz to written music . Analysis and performance of historical and contemporary examples will be included .

course_name: JOUR 505 The Practice : Journalism's Evolution as a Profession
description: Analyzes the history , ethics and evolution of journalism ; Students will be introduced to key innovations and innovators in journalism history as well as multimedia platforms . Open only to journalism majors .

A journalism immersion experience that orients and familiarizes students with the best practices and standards of cutting-edge multimedia , multi-platform fact gathering , reporting and storytelling . Open only to Journalism majors .
Students write , report , produce , code , promote (through social media) , and publish/air cross-platform stories in a converged news environment . Open only to Journalism majors .

course_name: News , Numbers and Introduction to Data Journalism
description: An overview of the basic quantitative analysis tools and techniques essential to give perspective to a journalistic story or to put it in context .
Explores the economics of the news industry and prepares students to navigate the journalism job market through practical exercises , practice interviews and cover letter-writing .

course_name: JOUR 553 Coding and Programming for Storytelling
description: Sketch , design and code a website from scratch , using HTML , CSS and jQuery plug-ins to tell a rich multimedia story . Open only to journalism majors .

course_name: JOUR 560 Seminar in Mass Communication Law
description: Analysis of major elements of mass communication law , legal issues in contemporary mass communication , and the impact of legal trends on professional journalists . Open only to journalism majors .
Seminar in selected topics in journalism .
Production of a journalism capstone project with multimedia elements for a master’s degree . Projects can be single stand-alone pieces , or series of pieces .

Pre-production of video documentary including selection of topic , diversity , ethical and legal problems , research and reporting techniques , interviewing , writing , balanced presentation , visual and audio literacy . Open only to journalism majors .

Production of video documentary including research and reporting techniques , writing , interviewing , field work , editing , legal issues , economics , aesthetics , balanced presentation , ethics , diversity and production problems .
Advanced multimedia news production ; preparation and treatment of form and content ; procedures , problems , ethics , and practice in operating a daily , 24-7 news outlet .
Advanced reportorial and analytical skills and techniques required for evaluating newsworthy events . Group research and publication of stories on important current topics .

Reporting and writing broadcast news ; analysis and practical experience ; role of the broadcast journalism reporter ; similarities and differences between media ; application of audio-visual equipment .

Focus on basic investigative reporting ; understand its history , how to access records , identify sources , use computer assisted reporting , report in a fair and ethical manner . Open only to journalism majors .

Writing , reporting and producing content for video and digital platforms ; similarities and differences between media ; application of audio-visual and digital equipment . Open only to journalism majors .

course_name: JOUR 495 Journalism for Mobile and Emerging Platforms
description: Create video , audio and graphic news and information using mobile and emerging technology  – such as phones , tablets and laptops – for non-broadcast platforms ; understand ethical and legal issues related to journalists working on mobile and emerging platforms .
Reporting for public radio-style news : writing , newsgathering , editing , vocal delivery . Techniques applicable for broadcast or Web audio stories . Open only to journalism majors .
Advanced production techniques for public radio-style reports : writing , sound , editing , narrative voice . Techniques applicable for broadcast features or Web audio documentaries .

course_name: JOUR 519 Advanced Writing and Reporting for Magazine and the Web
description: Focus on reporting and writing for magazine and the web , learning fundamental production skills , and pitching stories in the freelance market
Understanding new media through an economic lens . Applying knowledge by creating , reporting and delivering a communications or business strategy model .
Reporting and writing on religion ; survey of world religion , religion and public life — including politics , gender and science .
Reporting and writing on science ; survey of scientific research fields and evaluation of evidence and claims .

course_name: JOUR 596 Follow the Money : Business and Economics Reporting
description: Reporting and writing on business , economics and public finance ; students produce a series of professional projects for publication . Open only to journalism and specialized journalism majors .

course_name: JOUR 489 Hands-on Disruption : Experimenting with Emerging Technology
description: Exploration and experimentation of emerging technologies through the lens of journalism and hands-on prototyping

course_name: JOUR 494 Python Coding for Data Journalism
description: Python coding language to gather , parse and analyze data for investigative news reporting .

course_name: JOUR 496 Interactive Media Design for Publishing
description: Design , test and distribute engaging news and publishing apps . Learn concepts of interactive design , color , type , UX , and more for digital mobile/tablet platforms .

course_name: JOUR 497 Data Visualization and Interactive Tools
description: Present your data in tables , charts , graphs , maps , and complex multimedia pieces using readily available interactive tools .

course_name: JOUR 533 Web Journalism and Editorial Site Management
description: Report , edit , and manage a major news Website while operating its content management system ; understand best standards and practices in online site management . Open only to journalism majors .
Advanced concepts in online publishing ; focus on databases , editing , scripting and authoring applications for news Websites .

course_name: JOUR 555 Advanced Coding for Creative Storytelling
description: Focuses on advanced coding techniques for the creation of dynamic , interactive , multimedia and data-driven news stories on the web .
Execute data-driven projects and add context to news stories with advanced quantitative analysis tools and techniques .

course_name: ARCH 414 Perspectives in History and Theory in Architecture
description: Perspectives in Architecture and Urbanism is an advanced course that allows students to delve deeply into one aspect of world history , theory and/or contemporary issues to develop more focused and critical understanding of that discourse .

Introductory media workshop for new landscape architecture students in the 3-year graduate program . Topics include : hand drawing , measuring , architectural drawings , computer software tutorials , and field trips .
Development of methods and skills for the study of landscape architecture design and for project presentation , including natural resource and urban mapping .
Projects on urban sites with emphasis on cultural and ecological purpose and on urban place and form ; use of traditional and digital media .

Techniques , strategies , materials , and standards to topographic design and construction in landscape architecture . In-class labs practice basic grading , drainage design , and stormwater management .

course_name: ARCH 537 Urban Plant Ecology : Environmental Perspectives
description: Principles and concepts of plant ecology for urban planting design ; introduction to California native plant species and communities with field trips and case studies .
Developing and communicating landscape architecture design intent using visualization tools for three-dimensional studies .
Project strategies for urban infrastructure repair and intervention , phasing , and design of initial catalytic projects .

course_name: ARCH 538 L Urban Plant Ecology : Cultural Perspectives
description: Cultural perspectives of urban planting design and plant species found in Southern California emphasizing aesthetic , functional and ecological designs .
Learn and practice the process by which a landscape design is assembled through materials systems and design documentation .

Develop tools and knowledge to expand the performative boundaries of landscape architecture beyond common typologies . Topics range from ecological infrastructure to design with weather patterns . A systematic approach to case studies , landscape technologies , and field trips seeds the knowledge base and respresentational methods necessary to design and build these complex landscape performances .
Introduction to the principles and ethics , scope and activities , and types of organization for landscape architecture practice .
Fully integrated landscape place design ; reclamation sites at significant urban or natural locations .
Directed research option for the MLArch degree .

Investigation of computer graphic applications , emphasizing the role of computers in helping designers create and communicate using color (rendering) , form (modeling) , and time (animation) and the implications of future technological advancements .
Fundamental theories and meanings of computation as a technique in architectural design .
Comparative studies of professional practice between U .S . firms and firms in other countries .

course_name: ARCH 540 Topics in Media for Landscape Architecture
description: Exploration of emerging techniques for landscape architecture study , presentation and documentation ; topics vary from year to year ; may be repeated for credit when subject matter is different .

course_name: ARCH 546 Topics in Landscape Architecture : Issues and Practices
description: A broad range of developing urban landscape conditions and issues , both domestic and global , are given focused attention .

course_name: PPD 527 The Social Context of Planning
description: Examination of the formation of the modern urban environment with its consumer culture , social classes , and racial and ethnic diversity .

course_name: PPD 530 Historical Analysis of Urban Form and Planning Practice
description: Awareness , analysis , understanding , and influencing the city building process locally and regionally ; isolate and exercise tools and methods of visual literacy .
History of urban planning with an emphasis on the evolution of how planning shaped the physical environment in response to political , economic , and social issues .

course_name: PPD 640 Leadership Foundations : Competencies and Core Values
description: An intensive introduction to leading through core values . Focuses on developing leadership skills at the personal level to build a foundation for leadership at all levels .

course_name: PPD 641 Leading Individuals , Groups and Teams
description: Leadership styles in various settings ; team demographics , and dynamics ; problem-solving ; decision-making ; diversity and critical thinking skills ; effect of culture on small group communication ; managing conflict .

Strategic analysis ; strategic planning ; leadership ; performance measurement and management ; control systems ; organizational structure and networks ; organizational culture ; organizational learning and change .

course_name: PPD 643 Leading Transformations Across Sectors : Integrative Seminar
description: Application and practice of leadership skills working across the public , private and nonprofit sectors . Skills include negotiation , collaboration , communication , political management and ethical responsibilities .
Design and advancement of learning and motivation outcomes in various environments through a systematic examination and application of current research .
Fundamentals of human physical , motor , mental , social , and emotional development , spanning the prenatal period through late adulthood .
Appraises practices that maintain power ; creates strategies to empower individuals and marginalized groups by intervening to achieve equitable outcomes in education , professions and communities .
Overview of the concepts and procedures for assessment and evaluation of individual and overall performance in various learning environments .
Formulation and design of effective instruction ; emphasis on analysis of media characteristics and instrumentation requirements .
Selection and evaluation of media and technologies in support of instructional design based on a survey of current research and recommendations .
Design of learning environments through application of design principles ; project-based practice in aligning instructional design , media selection , and the features of learning spaces .
Students propose and design a capstone project that applies knowledge and skills learned throughout the program and prepare a coursework portfolio .
Students implement the capstone project and submit a portfolio that integrates program coursework .

Integrates leadership theory and practice with communication skills to improve individual , team , and organizational performance . Emphasizes interpersonal , presentation , and writing skills ; teamwork ; and value-based leadership .

course_name: LIM 500 Fundamentals of Library and Information Science
description: An overview of the history of recorded knowledge from ancient times to the digital age informed by the cultural implications of those eras . Open only to MMLIS students .

course_name: LIM 501 Fundamentals of Library Leadership and Management
description: Fundamentals of library leadership and management from past , present and future perspectives , including selected case studies .
The development of library collections in all formats emphasizing clientele interest , usage patterns , bibliographical and Website sources . Open only to MMLIS students .

course_name: LIM 503 Information Description , Organization , and Retrieval
description: An overview and critical analysis of current practices of information organization , cataloguing , access and reference services , including a conceptual understanding of these skills .

course_name: LIM 504 Research Methods in Library and Information Management
description: An overview of research methods in information management including the conceptualization of research problems , literature reviews , research design , sampling , measurement , data collection and data analysis . Open only to MMLIS students .

Apply concepts learned during the MMLIS program and investigate research questions and professional problems of concern to employers , their institutions and the profession at large . Open only to Library and Information Science majors .

course_name: Capstone in Library and Information Management
description: Student-driven research or project-based experience that integrates the knowledge from course work and applies it to current issues in the field .

course_name: ENGL 601 Introduction to Literary Editing and Publishing
description: Comprehensive introduction to the MA degree and its range of study , focusing on elements of the craft of editing and the literary marketplace .

course_name: ENGL 602 Writers in the World : Text and Context
description: Editing and publishing within the tradition of literary and cultural influences upon a wide range of authors , readers , and genres .

course_name: ENGL 603 The Editorial Experience : The Craft of Publication
description: An intensive workshop in applied English , coordinating literary analysis with editing and publication , including relationships with authors ; academic and trade presses ; journals ; editing , and design .

course_name: ENGL 604 The Nonfiction Experience : A Literary-Editorial Focus
description: Topics on literary and popular forms : profile portrait ; science writing ; food writing ; place and travel ; memoir ; and personal essay ; with venues for publication .

course_name: ENGL 607 Digital Publishing and Literary Writing for New Media
description: Discussion of literary texts combined with hands-on digital practice in composition , design , and fabrication for electronic publication , including formal , technical , and philosophical issues .

course_name: ENGL 608 Publishing on Both Sides of the Transom
description: Editorial and publishing workshop with an intensive hands-on student project following the progress of a single piece of writing from manuscript to print .

course_name: ENGL 609a Internship in Editing and Publishing : Eloquence and Ethics
description: Practical experience in the publishing world for acquiring skills and knowledge beyond the classroom .
Development of academic strategies for preparing articles for publication in scholarly journals . Aspects of publication will include abstracts , introductions , argumentation , style and footnotes .

course_name: FBE 587 Legal and Regulatory Environment of Long Term Care
description: Comprehensive overview of substantive business law topics and issues as they affect the long term care industry .

course_name: PPD 601 Management of Long-Term Care Organizations
description: History , development , trends ; major policy issues ; organization of systems ; principles and techniques of administration ; management of institutional and community based programs .

course_name: PPD 649 Concepts and Practices in Public Personnel Administration
description: Concepts of man and of work ; workforce ; government personnel systems , including merit concepts , classification , and compensation ; collective bargaining ; organizational justice ; training and development .

Study advanced concepts behind computational representations , algorithms , and mathematical foundations , and their applications in computeraided design and manufacturing . Develop hands-on computational skills in team projects .
Use of mechanical , electrical , and computer engineering , math , and computer science to design of high performance and sophisticated products and processes and systems involving mechatronic .
Managing the process design , interfaces and resources of service and manufacturing systems , based on the state of their processes .
Research leading to the master’s degree . Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department .

An overview of phytoplankton and zooplankton taxa , their morphologies and life histories using material collected from the local environment off LA and near the Phillip K . Wrigley Marine Science Center on Catalina Island .

course_name: Advanced Seminar on the Physiology of Marine Organisms
description: Physiological processes dictate survival potential , growth rates , and many other biological processes that affect the distribution of species in the oceans . Emphasis on the diverse environmental factors that influence physiological adaptations of marine organisms . Examples from a wide variety of marine organisms , from bacterial to animals , will be studied .

course_name: Advanced Seminar in Molecular and Microbial Ecology
description: Microorganisms dominate biological processes in the ocean . These species pose significant problems for estimating species diversity , abundance and activity . Examination of modern molecular biological approaches for analyzing aquatic microbial communities and their ecological roles .

course_name: Advanced Seminar in Remote Sensing and Modeling
description: Modern oceanographic methods for making remote measurements of aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems using satellite imagery and other means . Integrating these data into models that describe ecosystem structure and enable interpretation of ecosystem function .

course_name: Advanced Seminar in Population Genetics of Marine Organisms
description: An overview of the theory underlying population and quantitative genetics , with applications to marine systems . Basic evolutionary mechanisms (mutation , migration , drift , selection , nonrandom mating) and modern evidence for their roles in structuring genetic variation within and among marine populations .
Examination of the interplay between ocean biology and the cycling of carbon , nitrogen and other elements on a local , regional and global scale .

course_name: BISC 445 L Fundamentals of Vertebrate Biology
description: Evolution and comparative anatomy of vertebrates .

course_name: BISC 455 L Molecular Approaches to Microbial Diversity — Catalina Semester
description: Overview and practical application of genetic and immunological techniques for examining diversity and community structure of natural microbial assemblages in aquatic ecosystems .

Current genetic and biochemical analysis of replication , recombination , mutagenesis , and repair . Fundamentals of transcription and regulation of gene expression . Recent applications of genetic engineering and genome analysis .
Current topics in integrative biology including form , function and energy use throughout the lifespan in the context of genetics , natural selection and ecology .
Survey of current topics in evolutionary biology ; genetics , natural selection , ecology ; emphasis on higher order complex questions of lifespan , form , function , and energy use .

course_name: BISC 588L Quantitative Analysis for Biological and Earth Sciences
description: Basics of biometrics , biodiversity , quantitative methods in ecology , environmental impact assessments and other topics in quantitative analysis .
Basic microbiology of water , air , and soil . Application of microbiology to the practice of environmental pollution control .
Principles of marine paleoecology ; interrelationships between marine organisms and their environment in geologic time .
Concepts and methods for functional morphologic analysis of fossil marine invertebrates . Systematics theory and methodology , macro evolution , and broad biotic trends in the Phanerozoic .
Origin and characteristics of ocean basins ; marine sedimentary environments ; shoreline classification and character ; evolution of oceanic features .

Mesozoic and Cenozoic paleoceanography ; analytical approaches applied to water mass history , paleocirculation , paleoproductivity , nutrient cycling , and paleotemperature reconstruction . Lecture , readings , and research project .
Principles of chemical sedimentology and aquatic chemistry ; diagenesis , authigenesis , and the geochemical cycle .
Variations in the isotopic composition of elements in the earth’s crust with applications to geological problems , including geochronology , geothermometry , ore genesis , and crustal evolution .

Theoretical basis ; nuclide nomenclature , partition function ratios , mechanisms and rates of isotope exchange ; mass spectrometry and extraction techniques ; application of stable isotopes to geologic problems .
Microscopic fossils , especially foraminifera , their classification , the common genera , morphology , evolutionary trends ; laboratory and field techniques .

course_name: OS 512 Introduction to Chemical and Physical Oceanography
description: Principles of physical , chemical , and geological oceanography including discussions of air-sea interaction , biogeochemical cycling and the role of the ocean in modulating climate and atmospheric composition ; discussion section will cover formulation of basic calculations that illustrate these principles .
Coastal management issues in the context of public and private users competing for land resources , the costs and benefits of seaports , compare coastal development models .

course_name: MKT 543 Market Demand and Sales Forecasting
description: New product concept testing and life cycle forecasting , pricing and advertising response forecasting , consumer purchase intentions , judgmental marketing decision models , time series and regression analysis , computer methods .
Use of marketing research techniques and technologies such as databases and statistical tools to collect , analyze and act upon customer information .
All aspects of Internet marketing . Internet as a tool for marketing communication , sales and distribution , customer management . Role of paid advertising , search engines , Website design .

Design and implementation of marketing strategies applied to domestic and global business challenges that span multiple industries complimented by a consumer packaged goods marketing strategic plan project .

course_name: Professional Identity , Law and Ethics for Counselors
description: History of the field of counseling and professional identity development for counselors are addressed . Examination of current legal , ethical , and other professional issues in counseling .

course_name: Theories of Marriage and Family Therapy
description: Major psychotherapeutic orientations relating to family systems , marital relationships , and communications theory applied to the family unit .
Educational and psychological instruments ; psychometric concepts and the rationale for the use of psychological instruments in the counseling relationship .

course_name: EDUC 546 Psychopathology for Marriage and Family Therapy
description: Theories of psychological impairment emphasizing diagnosis of child and family dysfunction . Practice in utilizing DSM-IV classification of case studies .

course_name: Psychopharmacology and the Effects of Substance Abuse
description: Focus on the effects of psychotropic medication , alcohol , and other substances on behavior . The professional and ethical issues for marriage and family therapists .
Developmental issues and life events from infancy to old age and their effect upon individuals , couples , and family relationships .

course_name: Child and Elder Abuse and Domestic Violence
description: A review of laws governing mandated reporting of child and elder abuse , the procedures involved , as well as etiology , effects , and treatment interventions .
Examines relational development and change , strategies for intervention with couples , and selected issues in couples relationship functioning .

course_name: EDUC 635 Psychotherapy with Children and Adolescents
description: Training in unique diagnostic considerations in working with children and adolescents . Exposure to empirically supported treatment modalities for children and adolescents .
The physiological-psychological and socio-cultural variables associated with sexual identity and sexual behavior with an emphasis upon sexual dysfunctions .

course_name: EDUC 638 Cross-Cultural Counseling : Research and Practice
description: An examination of the cultural , socioeconomic , and language factors that may affect culturally differentiated populations ; alternative crosscultural counseling approaches .
Supervised clinical work with clients , including adults , couples , children , and families .
Supervised field experience in a clinical setting .

course_name: Marriage and Family Therapy Capstone : Leadership Project
description: An evidencebased leadership project , designed to enhance fieldwork site functioning . Includes needs assessment , literature review , project design , implementation , and evaluation .

course_name: GPPD 500a Global Policy Challenges and Solutions
description: Consideration of current public policy issues through informed discourse and debate ; analysis and policy arguments .

course_name: GPPD 510 Economic Foundations for Public Policy
description: Microeconomic foundations ; analysis of public sector problems ; markets ; producer and consumer theory ; private and social efficiency .
Issues across public/private partnerships ; leadership and followership in cross-sector settings ; organizational and institutional designs ; problem solving , negotiation and conflict resolution .

course_name: GPPD 530 Art and Craft of Public Policy Analysis
description: Foundations of public policy as a profession , and develops basic skills in policy analytic reasoning , policy design , normative analysis and ethics , and argumentation .

course_name: GPPD 540 Comparative Institutions and Policy Context
description: Theoretical and empirical foundations on how institutions affect policy performance ; comparative institutional analysis and framework ; approaches to organizing public action .

course_name: GPPD 550 Quantitative Methods for Public Policy
description: Economic theory and statistical inference methods to estimate the relationship between economic , social and political variables ; foundations of data-based argumentation , specifically in regards to public policy in an international context .
Methods utilized in the analysis of public policy choices ; ex ante and ex post analysis ; cost-benefit analysis ; decision and risk analysis ; applied social science methods .
Policy formulation and implementation in a comparative context and in the context of an East-West dichotomy .

course_name: GPPD 580 Policy Challenges in International Development
description: Overview of the overarching issues of problem definition of “development” and the policy implications of new ideas for development as it faces a new set of challenges in an increasingly globalized , complex , and interconnected world .
Hands-on experience in policy analysis . Participants learn to work on a specific , client oriented public policy issue , assess policy alternatives , and write an official report .

course_name: LAW 520 Introduction to U .S . Legal System
description: The basic structure of government in the U .S . , including the constitutionally mandated division of power in the federal government and the federal system of power sharing between state and federal systems . A comparative perspective on selected substantive and procedural matters , such as common law reasoning , jury trials , adversary process , and various aspects of civil procedure . Open to LLM students only .

course_name: LAW 822 Alternative Dispute Resolution Clause Drafting
description: Explores a variety of contract provisions , and teaches students the important drafting skills necessary to achieve a client’s goal .
Covers basic aspects of international commercial arbitration and prepares a USC Law School team for participation in the Willem C . Vis International Commercial Arbitration Moot .
Introduces students to the National Labor Relations Act , collective bargaining and the labor arbitration process . Students also prepare labor arbitration briefs .
Teaches the skills and substantive area of the law necessary to successfully mediate cases in the Edelman Children’s courthouse in Monterey Park .

Examination of the basic sources of law for federal and California jurisdictions , utilizing a vast array of sources from books to computer-assisted research and analyzing research methodology and techniques .

, 3 , 4This course introduces law students to the tools , concept , and language of business . It is premised on the belief that to excel as a business lawyer , one must understand the business world from the perspective of the clients one counsels and assists . The course will cover , in compressed form , the basic subjects from the MBA program which are most useful to lawyers .
Problems of integrating the corporate , securities , tax , business , antitrust , accounting and contractual aspects of corporate mergers and acquisitions .
, 3Students examine contracts and present to the class their assessment of why the specific provisions were drafted and possible alternatives and challenges to those provisions .
Regulation by state and federal agencies of issuance of , and trading in , stocks , bonds , and other securities . Particular reference to SEC regulations .

course_name: MATH 530a Stochastic Calculus and Mathematical Finance
description: Stochastic processes revisited , Brownian motion , Martingale theory , stochastic differential equations , Feynman-Kac formula , binomial models , basic concepts in arbitrage pricing theory , equivalent Martingale measure .

course_name: Financial Informatics and Simulation (Computer Labs and Practitioner Seminar)
description: Experimental laboratory trading for financial markets using double auctions : handling statistical packages for data analysis . Practical training in virtual market environments , using financial trading system software .
Research leading to the master’s degree . Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department .

Equilibrium model of finance economy ; absence of arbitrage ; complete and incomplete markets ; asset pricing theory ; representative agent pricing . Capital Asset Pricing Model , martingale property of security prices .
Theory of random differential equations and stochastic stability ; optimum linear and nonlinear filtering , with discussion of asymptotic behavior of filter .
Brownian motion , stochastic integrals , the Ito formula , stochastic differential equations , analysis of diffusion processes , Girsanov transformation , Feynmann-Kac formula , applications .

Deterministic control : calculus of variations ; optimal control ; Pontryagin principle ; multiplier rules and abstract nonlinear programming ; existence and continuity of controls ; problem of Mayer ; dynamic programming .

course_name: Economic and Financial Time Series II
description: Stock returns , predictability and volatility , random walk and variance-bounds tests , estimation of capital asset , multifactor , and derivative pricing models , term structure of interest rates .

Financial market equilibrium and partial equilibrium asset pricing in discrete and continuous time ; properties of equilibria with and without complete markets ; theory of option prices ; Black-Scholes pricing formula ; term structure of interest rates ; hedging strategies and managing market risk using options , futures and swaps ; hedging exchange-rates risks .

Alternative energy/power conversion including fuel cells , photovoltaic , batteries , and biologically inspired energy processes ; biomass conversion and utilization ; Environmental implications of alternative energy processes .

Thermochemistry , equilibrium , chemical kinetics , flame temperature , flame velocity , flame stability , diffusion flames spray combustion , detonation . Equations of motion including reaction , heat transfer , and diffusion .

course_name: Applications of Combustion and Reacting Flows
description: Advanced topics and modern developments in combustion and reacting flows including ignition and extinction , pollutant formation , microscale and microgravity combustion , turbulent combustion and hypersonic propulsion .

Thermodynamics of combustion processes . Reaction mechanisms of hydrocarbon combustion . Pollutant formation . Theories and application of thermochemical kinetics and reaction rate theories . Transport in reacting flows .

Review of basic nuclear physics , binding energy , reactor kinetics , thermal transport in reactor systems , radioactivity , shielding , reactor safety and health effects of radiation , risk assessment . Open only to graduate students .

Neutron-induced fission chain reactions , reactor criticality . Neutron transport and diffusion in nuclear reactors . Mathematical/computational foundation for diffusion theory and transport calculations for fission reactor design/analysis .
ecific problems and methods of analysis in mechanical systems design .

Symbolic and object-oriented modeling , product and process modeling for design and manufacturing , information models for computer integrated and collaborative engineering , information modeling for life-cycle engineering .

course_name: Elements of Vehicle and Energy Systems Design
description: IrregularDesign synthesis of aero/hydro/mechanical systems ; techniques of design ; conceptual thinking ; problem definition , configurational development , analytic engineering approximation , oral briefings and group problem solving .
State space representation , linearization , solution of state equations ; controllability and observability ; state feedback , state observers ; optimal control ; output feedback .
Introduction to systems architecture in aerospace , electrical , computer , and manufacturing systems emphasizing the conceptual and acceptance phases and using heuristics .
Review of analytical methods in heat conduction ; moving boundaries melting and freezing ; sources and sinks , anisotropic and composite media ; numerical methods for steady and unsteady problems .
Radiation properties ; black body radiation ; shape factors of radiation network analogy and solar radiation .
Physics of the interaction between phases , empirical and analytical methods of solution to relevant technological problems .

Introduction to fluid dynamics in the microscale . Scaling parameters , dynamic , thermodynamic , electroosmotic and electrochemical forces . Flow in microdevices , external flow measurement and control , microvalves and micropumps . Limited to students with graduate standing .
(Enroll in MASC 559 )
(Enroll in MASC 560 )
(Enroll in MASC 584 )
(Enroll in CE 542 )
(Enroll in MASC 583 )

Introduction to micro-electro-opto-mechanical systems ; scaling effects on material properties , fluid flows , dynamical behavior ; fabrication methods ; design considerations for MEMS sensors and actuators .

Principles and biomedical applications of micro-electromechanical systems (MEMS) and nanotechnology , including microfluidics , nanowire sensors , nanomotors , quantum dots , biofuel cells and molecular imaging .
Exploration of the technology methods and physical principles of MEMS , and survey various MEMS of current interest .
Thermal-fluid phenomena for nuclear power stations . Heat generation by nuclear reactions , conduction in fuel rods , and transport of generated heat by convection , boiling , and condensation .

Nuclear physics relevant to human health . Biological effects of radiation , quantification and measurement of different types of radiation affecting living tissue , radiation protection , nuclear accidents .

course_name: Nuclear Safety and Security : Human Performance and Safety Culture
